title: 113_s1001
content: The "Iran Export Embargo Act" is cited as the short title. Sanctions are imposed on the government of Iran under the Iran Freedom and Counter-Proliferation Act of 2012. Congress finds that the Government of Iran violates human rights and sponsors terrorism globally. The Government of Iran is the leading state sponsor of terrorism globally, with recent involvement in terrorist attacks in Bulgaria, Washington, DC, the Republic of Azerbaijan, Canada, and the Republic of Georgia. Iran is also in violation of multiple United Nations Security Council Resolutions regarding its nuclear activities. The Government of Iran violates multiple UN Security Council Resolutions by refusing to suspend nuclear activities, developing ballistic missiles, and supporting terrorism globally. The Government of Iran violates UN Security Council Resolution 1701 by transferring arms to terrorist groups in Lebanon and Gaza, supporting human rights abuses in Syria. The Government of Iran supports human rights abuses in Syria and is involved in transferring arms to terrorist groups in Lebanon and Gaza. The President will block all transactions involving property of individuals described in the Act within the United States or under the control of a US person. The President will prohibit foreign financial institutions from opening or maintaining correspondent accounts in the US if they have conducted significant transactions related to importation after a specific date. The President will impose sanctions on foreign financial institutions that knowingly conduct significant transactions related to the importation of goods or services from Iran on behalf of specified individuals. The President will impose sanctions on individuals who knowingly import, purchase, or transfer goods or services from specified persons in Iran. Sanctions will also be imposed on those involved in insurance and reinsurance transactions with Iran. The President will impose sanctions on individuals providing underwriting services, insurance, or reinsurance to specified persons in Iran, with an exception for those exercising due diligence. The President may not impose sanctions on underwriters and insurance providers who exercise due diligence in ensuring they do not provide services to specified persons in Iran. The President may not impose sanctions on underwriters and insurance providers who ensure they do not provide services to specified persons in Iran, including the state and Government of Iran, any entities owned or controlled by them, or those acting on their behalf. The President can impose sanctions on individuals or entities associated with the Government of Iran, including those owned or controlled by the government, acting on its behalf, or determined by the President to fall under these categories. These sanctions apply regardless of the person's listing in official publications. Sanctions can be imposed on individuals or entities associated with the Government of Iran, regardless of their listing in official publications. Subsections (c) and (d) apply to the exportation, importation, sale, or transfer of crude oil from Iran 180 days after the enactment of this Act.
